case_vignette: A 58-year-old woman with HIV infection is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of headaches, blurred vision, and confusion. Her current medications include antiretroviral therapy and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Neurological examination shows ataxia and memory impairment. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/μL. Analysis of her cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows lymphocytic predominant pleocytosis, and PCR is positive for Epstein-Barr virus DNA. An MRI of the brain with contrast shows a solitary, weakly ring-enhancing lesion with well-defined borders involving the corpus callosum.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing headaches, blurred vision, and confusion for the past two weeks.
Have there been any recent injuries to your head or neck?
No, I haven't had any recent injuries to my head or neck.
What is your age and gender?
I am a 58-year-old woman.
Do you have any other medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
Yes, I have HIV and I am currently on antiretroviral therapy and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
Have you experienced any weakness in your arms or legs, or any changes in your speech?
No, I have not experienced any weakness in my arms or legs, nor have I noticed any changes in my speech.
Do you have a history of similar symptoms in the past, or is this the first occurrence?
This is the first occurrence of these symptoms.
Has anyone in your family had similar symptoms or been diagnosed with neurological disorders?
No, nobody in my family has had similar symptoms or been diagnosed with neurological disorders.
Final Diagnosis: Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML)
